data.title: Reversed Look-and-say
data.solution:
#################################
#  REVERSED LOOK-AND-SAY
#################################

__author__ = 'miguel.herraez'
import string

def mySplit(element):
    """
    Reads and groups numbers
    """
    myGroups = []
    for i,e in enumerate(element):

        if i==0:
            myGroups.append( [1,e] )
        else:
            if e == myGroups[-1][1]:
                myGroups[-1][0] += 1
            else:
                myGroups.append( [1,e] )

    return myGroups

def lookAndSay(element):
    """
    :param element: Element of the look-and-say series
    :return: The next element of the look-and-say series
    """
    # 1) Split the previous element into groups of equal adjacent numbers
    groups = mySplit(element)

    # 2) Build up the new element
    myList = [str(item) for sublist in groups for item in sublist]
    newElement = string.join(myList,'')

    return newElement


############################################################################
s = raw_input()
#s = raw_input('Introduce the element of the look-and-say series: ')
# s = '122113112211'
newElement = s
elements = [s,]

while True:
    nextElement = newElement

    if len(nextElement)<=1:
        break

    # 1) Split the previous element into pairs
    groups = zip(nextElement[::2], nextElement[1::2])
    # print groups

    # 2) Build up the new element
    myList = [int(n)*number for n,number in groups]
    newElement = string.join(myList,'')
    # print newElement

    # 3) Check reversibility
    if lookAndSay(newElement) != nextElement:
        # print 'Wrong iteration!!'
        newElement = nextElement
        break

    # 4) Check repeatibility
    if newElement in elements:
        # print 'Repeating!!'
        newElement = nextElement
        break

    elements.append(newElement)

print newElement
data.statement:
Given an element of the Look-and-say series, you must walk the series in the reverse direction until you find the first valid element of the series.

The Look-and-say series transforms a given number by changing a "spoken" interpretation of that number into a numerical format. The spoken interpretation of a number takes groups of digits and states the count of repeated digits in each group.

`13112221 =>
    1  3  11  222  1 =>
        "One 1, one 3, two 1s, three 2s, one 1" =>
            11  13  21  32  11 =>
                1113213211`

Given the above example of the Look-and-say series, if you were given "1113213211" as an input, the first step in walking the series in reverse would yield "13112221". Be careful after each iteration because the process is not always reversible...


For example:


`1211 => 
    1 x "2" + 1 x "1" = 21 => 
        2 x "1" = 11 => 
            1 x "1" = 1. This is the last possible step`


`41 => 
    4 x "1" = 1111 => 
        1 x "1" + 1 x "1" = 11. This step is not reversible!

The solution is 1111`


You can find detailed information of this sequence in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Look-and-say_sequence.
data.constraints:
Log([[n]]) < 100
No digit appears consecutively more than 9 times for any element in the series.
